title.narrative: DRA B.Ready Upscale Global Hum. Team

description.narrative: B-READY has now been tested in the Philippines (B.Ready A-05666), and has initial funding to be piloted in Sudan. To make the jump from ‘pilot’ to ‘preparing for scale’ B-READY needs to: 1. Evidence the current B-READY Model for iterative improvement, advocacy and impact: The project will cover 2 new locations in the Philippines, and continue in its current operational area to generate evidence including a Randomized Control Trial, to create iterative improvement, advocacy materials and build B-READY for adoption. 2. Codification of the B-READY Philippines and Global Scale Model includes mapping similar initiatives elsewhere for collaboration or learning, considering ‘fertile’ areas for scale up (financing, locations, actors, policy routes), choosing astrategic scale up trajectorybased on lessons learned, and then a collaborative codification process linking the Philippines National Model, with a Global ScaleModel and ‘testing’ these with new funders and implementers to ensure greatest impact, cost-efficiency and ethical risk management. 3. Building B-READY for Sustainability at Scale by practically testing local and global sustainability pathways through government uptake (Philippines), private sector finance business models, global FbF, and pre-emptive financial tools/mechanisms currently under-discussion. Furthermore, there will be global advocacy, influencing and knowledge sharing, having B-READY and its Scale Model featured in many appropriate forums, exposure visits, webinar presentations, socialisation workshops, targeted policy papers, and discussions with strategic actors to build new partners for adoption. Oxfam in Philippines capacity is based on advocacy, resilience, localhumanitarian leadership, digital financial inclusion and cash programming, for which they have received awards from Google and the Australian Government on accelerating financial inclusion with technology. They will provide technical advice, finance private sector oversight, coordination of actors, advocacy in country, gathering evidence and codification of B-READY. OGB will host the policy adviser from the Global Humanitarian Team.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam is an international confederation of 17 organizations working together in more than 90 countries. Oxfam International was formed in 1995 by a group of independent non-governmental organizations. Their aim was to work together for greater impact on the international stage to reduce poverty and injustice. The name "Oxfam" comes from the Oxford Committee for Famine Relief, founded in Britain in 1942. The group campaigned for food supplies to be sent through an allied naval blockade to starving women and children in enemy-occupied Greece during the Second World War. As well as becoming a world leader in the delivery of emergency relief, Oxfam International implements long-term development programs in vulnerable communities. We are also part of a global movement, campaigning with others, for instance, to end unfair trade rules, demand better health and education services for all, and to combat climate change. Today, there are 17 member organizations of the Oxfam International confederation. They are based in: Australia, Belgium, Canada,France, Germany, Great Britain, Hong Kong, Ireland, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, The Netherlands, New Zealand, Quebec, Spain and the United States. The Oxfam International Secretariat is based in Oxford, UK. The Secretariat runs advocacy offices in Brussels, Geneva, New York, Washington DC and Brasilia. Oxfam GB is an actor in the implementation of this project.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
